course.description: Inner workings of modern digital computer systems and tradeoffs at the hardware-software interface. reviews.title: Interesting Content, Mediocre Professor
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers low-level computing, such as how computers store signed numbers, MIPS assembly language and how a basic processor works.

1. Introduction to Digital Logic
    • Logic gates
    • Combinational & sequential logic circuits
    • Boolean algebra & K-map
2. Data Representation
    • Signed & unsigned integers (2's complement)
    • Signed & unsigned floats (IEEE754)
3. MIPS Assembly Language
    • Arithmetic operations
    • Control flow statements & functions
    • Instruction formats
4. Arithmetic for Computers
    • Arithmetic Logic Unit
    • Integer Multiplication & Division
5. MIPS Processor
    • Single-cycle datapath & control
    • Pipelined Processor
6. Memory Hierarchy
    • Principle of Locality
    • Cache

This course materials are well prepared but you need lots of memorization. The MIPS processor is probably the most difficult chapter in the entire course. Luckily since the semester is in online mode, the mid-term and final are open book and open notes so I don't need to memorize.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Lam is a very passionate lecturer and he is willing to interact with students and answer questions. His English is also very fluent and sometimes he talks too fast.

However, I'm not a fan of his teaching style. Firstly, he makes extremely messy notes while teaching (which he acknowledges this problem lol). He would put many meaningless circles and lines across the slide he is explaining and turns the entire slide into a graffiti. It's very easy to get lost when you are trying to figure out which part of the slide he's teaching.

Also, he sometimes spends excessive amount of time (eg. half an hour) to revise the last lecture's content. After realizing that, he would then skip through slides and explanations to catch up the teaching progress.

I highly recommend taking Li Xin's session since her teaching is highly organized and well-explained.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is fine, but getting a good grade is difficult since the course is competitive.

Mid-term - 30%

reviews.comment_workload:
I find the workload acceptable.

The homework is not too time consuming and each homework can be completed within a day. The project is a little bit time consuming since you need to program in assembly. The most time consuming part is debugging your assembly program, in which a single bug could take hours to find.

Since this semester is online-mode and the exams are open notes, it saves so much time memorizing the lecture notes and relief the workload for quite a bit.

reviews.comment_content:
1. Digital Logic : it's my first time learning logic gates and using them to perform various operations. Before exam, I  recommend you prepare some tricks to simplify complicated boolean expressions.

2. Data Representation : pretty interesting to see how data are represented at low level like using IEEE 754 scheme and 2's complement. Also  here you will deal with bit array all the time so before exam, I  recommend you prepare some tricks to quickly manipulate powers of 2 e.g. \sum_{k=0}^{n-1}2^k = 2^{n}-1 (tho this actually comes from geometric series).  

3.  Instruction Set Architecture (ISA) and MIPS Assembly
     Language : pretty interesting to learn Assembly
     Language, it lets you experience a new style of programming. Before exam, I recommend you to equip yourself with ability to read & understand a block of MIPS code without any hint, you should be able to tell what the code is doing precisely.

4. Computer Arithmetic : here you'll learn ALU and how to implement arithmetic like multiplication & division with ALU. Before exam, I recommend you familiarize yourself with the every step of those algorithms including the states of the operands.  

5. Processor and pipeline : here you learn to implement various MIPS instructions with hardware. Before exam, I recommend you add additional hardware to the processor and implement more MIPS instructions, just play around.

6. Memory System : we only learned up to directed mapped cache this semester. Dr. Lam said if there's one thing that you should take away from COMP2611, then it has to the principle of locality (temporal and spatial). This principle is applied everywhere in CS and even other fields.

reviews.comment_content:

reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is not as bad as the others say, and is actually quite good.

Project 15%
Homework 15%
Midterm 30%
Final 40%

I got full marks for the project and homework, 0.5 bonus points in the project, and +1.2 SD for both midterms and finals.
The overall course grade was 93.5 -> A+

The exams are very straightforward. No tricky questions. Everything in the exam was covered in the lectures. If you review the materials thoroughly, you can probably score at least 80%. The only reasons you can have points deducted are either because you ran out of time (the exams were one-way-forward) or careless mistakes. Since you can't go back to previous questions in the exam, you may be tempted to triple-check your answers, but don't. You will end up running out of time.

I recommend reserving 3 days for revision for the midterms and finals. Moreover, the exams were open-book, but only printed materials are allowed, so a good cheat sheet will help a lot.

You can get up to 5 points from your project bonus. That's 5 points to the overall course grade, not the project grade, so it is totally worth it. You need to submit a proposal first, but there is no penalty if you can't finish what you propose or decide to work on something outside your proposal, so you can propose as many items as you want. The final bonus grade depends on what you end up being able to implement.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite manageable.

There were 4 homework, around 2 hours each.

The project took around 3 hours.

The project bonus part took me a whole day, because the TA who wrote the java emulator is a war criminal and I spend hours making sense of the code.

(The base portion of the project is in assembly but you need to modify the MIPS emulator in java for the bonus part)

Exams require around 3 days of revision each. Doing lots of past papers is necessary.
